head.citation-title: Silk materials for drug delivery devices
head.abstracts: One of the big challenges of medicine today is to deliver drugs specifically to defected cells. Drug delivery devices have been paid more attention lately in order to deliver the drug to specific area as well as sustained and long-term release, with minimal to no toxicity to healthy tissues. The ideal system should be able to cross physiological barriers and access different tissues, and also be provided in a targetable form aimed at enhancing cell specificity of the carrier. The polymers or biopolymers used for this purpose should be possess biodegradability, biocompatibility, increase the stability of the drug, low toxicity, simple and mild preparation methods, offer a valuable tool to novel drug delivery systems in the present scenario. Silk nanoparticles, especially silk fibroin, overcome barriers set by synthetic nondegradable nanoparticles made of silicone, polyethylene glycol and degradable polylactic acid-polyglycolic acid polymers. It has demonstrated high efficacy in cancer cells, silk fibroin-derived particles also enhance intracellular uptake and retention resulting in down modulation of more than one pathway due to longer availability of the therapeutic. Because of these evidences, silk materials have been widely explored for its applications as drug delivery devices. © 2012 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

coredata.dc:description: One of the big challenges of medicine today is to deliver drugs specifically to defected cells. Drug delivery devices have been paid more attention lately in order to deliver the drug to specific area as well as sustained and long-term release, with minimal to no toxicity to healthy tissues. The ideal system should be able to cross physiological barriers and access different tissues, and also be provided in a targetable form aimed at enhancing cell specificity of the carrier. The polymers or biopolymers used for this purpose should be possess biodegradability, biocompatibility, increase the stability of the drug, low toxicity, simple and mild preparation methods, offer a valuable tool to novel drug delivery systems in the present scenario. Silk nanoparticles, especially silk fibroin, overcome barriers set by synthetic nondegradable nanoparticles made of silicone, polyethylene glycol and degradable polylactic acid-polyglycolic acid polymers. It has demonstrated high efficacy in cancer cells, silk fibroin-derived particles also enhance intracellular uptake and retention resulting in down modulation of more than one pathway due to longer availability of the therapeutic. Because of these evidences, silk materials have been widely explored for its applications as drug delivery devices. © 2012 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:title: Silk materials for drug delivery devices
